Henrik Mittelholzer you are missing my point. It should not rain more in deserts. The seasons depend on what type of desert it is. A subtropical desert will be hot and dry year round, while a temperate desert will be cold in the winter and hot in the summer. I’m guessing Minecraft’s desert is a temperate desert given the cacti and the dead bushes. The desert is not flooded with rain in spring and autumn. In fact, Minecraft’s whole temperature system is a bit flawed and will need to be changed if sasons were to be implemented.

A small sort of write up of my own for this topic I did before finding this post.

All biomes receive a sub-class state for seasons. (( Example: Forest (Winter), Forest (Spring), Forest (Autumn), Forest (Summer) ))


Certain biomes will be the same year round, such as icy mountains always snowing and being frozen, or deserts, savannas, mesas, and rain forests never snowing.


Depending on the season, there would be mechanical and visual effects in certain temperate/mid range biomes such as plains or forests, with effects as, but not limited to.

Winter
-Trees lose their leaves, turn grey, something (Maybe change to a mess of sticks/branches as their texture? No longer dropping apples when broken, only sticks sometimes) 
-Snow falls instead of rain
-Crops grow slower or not at all
-Night lasts longer
-Maybe other texture changes, like more yellow grass
-Maybe mob changes, like the spawning of 'frozen' slower but more damaging zombies? Take extra damage from fire.

Spring
-Rains more often
-Leaves return to normal
-crops return to normal
-Snow and ice melts
-days return to normal length
-Some trees may have blossoms?

Summer
-Days last longer

Fall
-days return to normal length
-Leaves on trees become shades of orange, red, etc
-Trees gain a light particle effect sometimes of falling leaves
-Maybe other texture changes, like more yellow grass

Would be optional as a yes/no thing in world creation as "Seasons Mode" with sub options for "Normal Seasons" or "Long Seasons" With normal seasons likely being around 3 moon phases, with long being 5-6 moon phases.

((And as a roleplay server owner, it'd be really nice for some way to adjust the length with data packs or plugins to better suit server needs like mine.))

Games mechanic wise I feel though it should be a toggable feature, like an on and off feature to decide if you want to use it. Also, I think two ways the game could detect the season is by time zone differentiation, manual entry, or by the national day the season starts depending on the country. The idea of seasons is a great one. I really, really hope that Mojang gives Minecraft players the option to play with seasons. It will make the game more dynamic and interesting overall.

I've seen a few winter ideas regarding leaves. Some suggest no leaves at all while others suggest a gray tint. I would advocate for leaf textures simply turning white, as if the snow was coating any remaining leaves. I think, along with snow on the ground, biomes would truly become a winter wonderland of sorts. Also, the only biomes to not see snow should be: deserts, jungles, savannahs, and mesa biomes. The rest should all see snow! Swamps should perhaps not see snow, but maybe experience occasional ice, with the water and ponds freezing up? 

The ideas for the other seasons I have seen sound spectacular, especially autumn. 

As seasons has become more and more relevant in the Minecraft community, many people have expressed their interest in this idea. Seasons youtube videos have garnered thousands of likes with many people expressing their love of this idea. I hope Mojang listens! 

I sincerely hope Mojang puts seasons into the game in 1.15. I do not believe that seasons should take up an entire update themselves, but should be added to an update that's planned in the future (hopefully 1.15 so we get them soon!)

That' a REALLY NICE IDEA! There is a mod called Serene Seasons that does almost the same thing, but having it in the vanilla game would be much better. But is would have to be good, realistic seasons changing, colors, temperature... I've always wondered about having seasons in minecraft.

I think seasons could definitely work if done carefully and correctly, here’s how I’d do it. Each season would have a smooth transition for the changing textures of the grass and the leaves, each seasonal phase lasting about 200 minutes or 10 minecraft days. Player placed leaves would not change, however saplings planted by the player (once grown into trees) would change. TL;DR at bottom
_________________________________________________________________________
**Winter:** Most tree leaves (except spruce ones) would take on a branchy texture (dropping only sticks) in most biomes except jungle and hot biomes and grass could appear frosty and have slippy properties in most biomes (except hot ones or jungle) Snowfall could occur in cool biomes, be heavier in snowy ones and eventually melt in spring (snow layers already melt in biomes that arent cold in bedrock edition, however there are no actual seasons so it’s not the most useful feature for now). Crops wouldn’t grow at all without bonemeal, hunger would go down 1.5 times quicker in winter unless you’re next to a heat source, perhaps cooked foods would provide greater saturation in winter than non cooked foods? Husks could also be prevented from spawning in winter and maybe snow golems could spawn in random places too? Water would also freeze over except in hot biomes and jungle.

___________________________________________________________________________
**Spring:** Currently Minecraft is in eternal spring, the only differences to current minecraft could be blossom on most trees (pink or white) (not jungle and spruce ones, nor ones in deserts.) Creepers could be strongest in spring, their damage dealt increasing by 1 or even 2 hearts. More passive animals would spawn in every biome and crops could grow faster and have a chance of not using up bonemeal when bonemealed.

___________________________________________________________________________
**Summer:** Creepers (being plants) could burn in daylight (except in cold biomes) and strays would be rarer due to the heat but husks could have a chance of spawning in most biomes except for cold ones. In cold biomes it would rain instead of snow and Steve’s hunger would not go down as quick but getting set on fire would last longer. The leaves on trees could be a vibrant green (alpha minecraft green) and the grass a wheaty colour in most biomes except cold and hot ones. Maybe in hot biomes sudden fires could occur and thunderstorms be more common.

___________________________________________________________________________
**Autumn:** Rain would be far more common and so would all the monsters seeing as it is the month of Halloween, endermen would rarely spawn however due to it being a wetter month. Crops would start to grow slower (an early sign of winter approaching) harvest season and leaves could break and disappear faster after chopping all the wood on a tree. The grass could gain a brownish muddy top texture and if under certain trees a leafy overlay.

**TL;DR:** Essentially the only thing really changing each season would be certain mob spawning rates, the colour and/or texture of grass and leaves, the chance and location of downfall (snow/rain) and the rate at which hunger or saturation goes down.

An alternative idea might be to have a "base biome" parameter for all biomes and have them all shift down or up daily by a "variable" state which follows a sin curve or similar. This would allow automatic foliage color change as well as slow transitions between seasons instead of suddenly waking up one day and all the leaves are suddenly red. It would also allow for specific weather events like heat waves or blizzards by suddenly shifting the temperature greatly.

We might do well to add a separate humidity in addition to the existing temperature parameter, but this may be unnecessary.

All that is left to do is add a spring and/or autumn-style leaf texture for deciduous trees and cacti.

Rain and the "warm/dry" status melt fallen snow but not player-placed snow, kind of like leaves. Work in some way to wither saplings into dead bushes under specific but avoidable conditions.

Set an established Minecraft year of 100 or so days, or something which can keep snow height in snow biomes relatively stable.

Be able to affect seasons in cheats.

In any case, it is important to make sure the changes are mostly aesthetic.

The addition of seasons would be desirable, but this raises some questions that should be considered.

  • What would be the effects of seasons on a world?
  • How would seasons affect the growth of crops and the breeding of animals?
  • What would be the seasonal effects in each biome, if any?
  • Would seasons have any detrimental effects on the player?
  • What changes would be required to the Minecraft weather model?
  • How long would seasons last? What would be the length of the seasonal year?
  • Are seasons tied to the moon cycle?
  • Would this include modifications to the behaviour of the sun and moon so seasons have a visual indication?
  • Would new items be added to aid the tracking of seasons such as a calendar item?
  • Would seasons be optional per world?
  • Can seasons be controlled by game rules?

Effects on crops and animals

Seasonal effects have been discussed in depth by others so I'll touch on this lightly.

I expect a prominent part of seasons would be differences in crop growing speed and the breeding of animals. Animals might breed more easily in spring, such as a shorter breeding cooldown, better chances of multiple births (twin lambs, litters of pigs) or higher chances of chicks from eggs. Breeding cooldown could be longer in winter. Crop plots go dormant in winter: they grow clops slowly and they don't dry out.

Effect on the player

I don't expect any detrimental effects on the player, except incidental effects. Example: Blizzards could have reduced visibility (as low as 2 chunks) but the cold won't actually harm the player.

Weather model

Overhauling the weather model would be required. Apart from snow/rain depending on the time of the year, other changes would be required. Biome-dependent rain in specific seasons: Jungles could get more rain in wet seasons, deserts could get rain in summer from storms. Savannahs could get wet seasons that turn them green. Overcast weather could be added as a separate weather type instead of just being the manifestation of rain in deserts.

Length of the year

This needs some discussion. Some people have put out their ideas for the season length without any explanation and this isn't convincing. Why must seasons have a particular length? 24 hours of gameplay give 72 Minecraft days. How many seasons would pass in that time?

I think it's a bad idea to have short seasonal year lengths. Eight or 10 days for a season is too short. A player could go mining underground for a few hours and miss multiple seasons before they resurface.

It is also a very bad idea to tie the seasons to real-world months. Not only does that give a year is that too long (potentially thousands of days), it also fails to consider that not everyone experiences the same seasons at the same time of year. In some parts of the world, October is a spring month. In others, it's in the dry or wet season.

Finally, all months and seasons should be the same length. Why complicate things needlessly?

So what would be a reasonable year length? Some possible ideas:

  • one Minecraft seasonal month = 1 lunar month (8 days), 12 seasonal months per year. This gives seasons of 24 days and a Minecraft year of 96 days. This is the shortest year length that is plausible.
  • one Minecraft seasonal month = 24 days, one season = 72 days, a year = 288 days. This allows players to log on to a server once a day and log in during a different season. (Ignoring beds.)
  • One seasonal month = 32 days, a season = 96 days, one year = 384 days. This is the closest approximation to the 365-day year that preserves Minecraft's tendency to use powers of 2 to count things. This is perhaps the longest plausible year length.

All of these have seasonal months that are multiples of 8, to match the current lunar cycle. However, the lunar cycle can be changed.

Sun and Moon

In the real world, the seasons are driven by the length of the day and the height of the sun. This could be incorporated into Minecraft with the sun taking a tilted path across the sky and the sun having a different altitude in the sky over a year. The Minecraft world could have a "latitude" that controls the motion of the sun. The sun could pass to the north or the south, and high world latitudes could allow the midnight sun to occur at midsummer. This would give a visual indication of the seasons by the motion of the sun. Players may have a lot of fun tracking this and building their version of Stonehenge.

The moon would also need to follow the same path as the sun. Not only does this mean the moon would have a tilted path too, this implies that the moon may need to be altered so it's correctly placed in the sky in relation to the sun at all times. Crescent moons would be near the sun, and only full moons would be opposite the sun.

The moon cycle need not remain at eight days. It can be altered if desired.

Would eclipses occur?

New items

If seasons are added, it may require the addition of a calendar item. This would be similar to a clock item except for seasons.

A similar item for tracking the moon phases may be helpful too.

Game rules

Seasons should be controlled by a small set of game rules. It should be possible to turn them on or off and configure various parameters.

I thought of this idea also and here is how I would implement it in a logical way: 

  • The seasons will include summer, fall, winter, and spring in that order
  • Seasons would occur across all biomes excluding desert, jungle, snowy plains, ice pillars, and oceans. (At least what I can think of off the top of my head, add more biomes that would make sense if you want to) 
  • The use of seasons would be toggleable in world creation
  • Each season would last three moon cycles
  • The main feature of a seasonal update would be the leaf blocks changing colors (due to being a major part of how people recognize what season it is in the real world and would create a major atmospheric effect) 

Here are particular ideas for each specific season. (Any excluded thing would remain normal as in the same as Minecraft without seasons, anything with "(maybe)" following it means doesn't have to be included in the game but would fit in nicely)

Summer:

  • Game temperature would be higher
  • Less rain (maybe) 
  • Longer days (maybe)
  • Crops will have a lower tick speed (due to the raised temperature, maybe)

Fall:

  • Leaf blocks (excluding spruce) will turn into colors of yellow, orange, and red depending on the tree
  • Leaf blocks (excluding spruce) will have a falling leaves particle effect under them (maybe)
  • Leaf blocks (excluding spruce) would have another texture that is more transparent (have fewer leaves, maybe)

Winter: 

  • Game temperature would be lower
  • Leaf blocks (excluding spruce) would have a texture of dead branches and would only drop sticks
  • Or leaf blocks (excluding spruce) would change to the color white
  • Spruce leaf blocks would change to the color white
  • It would snow instead of rain (due to lower temperature) 
  • It would snow more often resulting in snow-covered ground and keeping it covered (maybe)
  • White leaf blocks would have a snowfall particle effect under them (maybe)
  • Water sources have a chance of turning into ice blocks (maybe)
  • Shorter days (maybe) 
  • Crops will have a lower tick speed (due to the lowered temperature, maybe)

Spring: 

  • Certain leaf blocks (excluding spruce) would change to the colors of pink or white to represent blossoms (maybe)
  • Leaf blocks (excluding spruce) would have another texture that is more transparent (have fewer leaves, maybe)
  • Rains more often (maybe)

These ideas would be most of the main features of a seasonal update or could just be a small add on to another type of update. These ideas are only my opinion of what should be included. I just feel this would be the most logical approach for an update that includes seasons and its details. Feel free to comment on more ideas that would make sense if you have any. I would like to see them. :) 

(Sorry about the long post, just want it all out there)

A compilation of the best ideas from the comments and a couple of my own ideas/variations on these ideas:

  • Add spring and fall seasons to make smoother transitions.
  • Different crops thrive at different times of year.
  • Make hostile mob spawning more common in winter (but only in harder difficulties, setting apart the harder difficulties, which are too easy, from the easy ones).
  • Make seasons last three moon cycles, like in real life, so it's not so abrupt, frequent, or game-changing.
  • Make "seasons" a world option that can be changed without cheats.
  • Make Strays spawn instead of Skeletons in winter.
  • Trees lose most of their leaves in winter and winter biomes (unless they're trees native to that biome). This makes leaves less annoying if they're not wanted.
  • Warm biomes have seasons, but the only difference is the frequency of rainfall.

Seasons shouldn't be based purely on boreal climates where snow is common in winter and not common at other times. There should be more variety. This variety can be managed adequately by introducing a few new biomes. Some example biomes:

Oceanic Forest - Does not usually snow in winter, storms are more frequent in summer, small temperature range during the year. This biome only occurs next to oceans. (The oceans moderate the temperatures so the summers are cooler and winters are warmer.) Example: New Zealand.

Cold Desert - Similar to a normal desert, but has a different vegetation mix and occasional cobblestone outcrops. Cold winters. Strays can spawn in winter instead of skeletons. This desert can be placed next to an icy biome instead of a regular desert, making it somewhat rare. Example: Gobi Desert, Mongolia.

Existing biomes need consideration as to frequency of snowfall, if any, and which seasons have rain or snow, if any.

Examples:

Taiga gets snow in winter. Cold taiga gets snow in spring and autumn as well, and the snow melts only in summer. Savannas get rain in summer (wet season) and turn green in summer. Deserts get rain only in summer and only in storms. Plains get less rain than forests.

It is clear that if seasons are implemented, the weather model must be changed as well, to permit more variable weather. A possible weather model can use 1D Perlin noise to simulate precipitation, and a simple sine wave for the temperature, adjusted as needed.

Good idea, but I think biomes like jungles and deserts (and savannahs) should have seasons (instead of being excluded), but instead of the 4 seasons we are used to, they would have "dry" and "wet" seasons, just like they do in real life (deserts/savannahs would be in dry season most of the year, and jungles would be in wet season most of the year).

Additionally, each biome should have seasons last different numbers of days; some biomes would get to "winter" sooner than others and would have it last longer. Here is a chart showing what I mean (each square represents 1 day):

Finally, I think each moon cycle should instead represent a month, and roughly 3 months would exist per season. 8 days per season just seems way too fast.

Just a reminder for people who suggest tracking real-world seasons: July is a winter month in some parts of the world. In other parts of the world, it's the wet season or the dry season. How would you account for that?

This is why adding seasons to a world would require an option to be selected somewhere, either as a global option or when creating or editing a world. Some pre-configuration of seasons is inevitable, even with real-world seasons. The game won't necessarily know where you are (think global VPNs), or what your seasonal preferences are. You would need to tell it. That doesn't mean real-world seasons shouldn't be considered, but they need to be considered really carefully.

Having a range of configurable seasonal options has merit and should be considered.

  • Does the world have a warm climate or a cold climate?
  • Are the seasons extreme (continental) or moderate (maritime)?
  • Are real world seasons followed?

If so:

  • What part of the real world?

If not:

  • How long is a year? What time of the year does the game start?
  • Do seasons progress or is the game locked to a single season? If so, what season?
  • What is the latitude of the game world?
  • What is the axial tilt?

Summer: more rain and husks will occasionally spawn at night. Enemies spawn at a rate of 60% as opposed to default (spring).

Fall: Less rain and grass appears darker green. Leaves on trees appear brownish as well. Crops will also begin to grow 50% slower than they usually do. Mob spawning is increased by 50% as opposed to default (spring)

Winter: Snow starts falling and water will become frozen, unless there is a light source near it. Any oceans or rivers that aren't "warm" will be completely frozen as well. As it stands, mobs don't feel like real creatures; they just wander aimlessly, while in reality, they are finding food, avoiding predators, and... increasing the pool of their species; they are busy and complex. It just takes research and lots of creativity to deepen the mobs and give them a personality.

Meteorology, so surprisingly, is in the same predicament as the mobs. It could be a tool to increase gameplay, and it does so for fishing and getting mob heads, but they are certainly not direct nor exciting features. Weather is not a thing to directly worry about in Minecraft, it is simply atmospheric, and affects mob behaviour under its certain conditions.

Minecraft meteorology can be enhanced in many, many, many ways, just like backpacks and ocean waves. That is the main reason it is hard to implement something like a weather update. It is not because the idea of seasons themselves are not Vanilla-like, but rather because there are so many things to consider, computer performance, game balancing, quality, and not eliminating Minecraft Icons that remind us what the game is about are among the top concern. But again, weather in Minecraft when done properly should only make the game better for most people. That is what these updates are about!
Here are a few ways to prevent restriction by limited computer performance, invalidation from game balancing rules, bring high quality updates, and keep our creeper flag from falling.

Computers come in all shapes and sizes, however, it is the little ones that need attention. It is not right to just leave them in the dust. It requires squeezing as much out for the little ones and there are several settings that can be fine tuned to do just that. Keeping major features away from low performance computers is not required, but realizing a computer's parameters, realizing the easiest parts of the update to abridge, and realizing one's own sanity to enjoyability ratio are key steps in finding out the best settings. (As you might be able to tell, I don't know all the different ways to help slow computers be more compatible with performance).

Balancing rules keeps the player and the game in check. Without the principal of balancing, Minecraft would either be too easy or too hard. As Minecraft is complex and full, so too would the balancing principals. However, recognising and improving balancing rules requires the mechanics of the updates to be understood, so I will go over them.

Temperature –Sun Exposure

Temperature and radiation are one of the building blocks for the other Elements. In a savanna, jungle, or desert (equatorial biome) at 12:00 PM, the temperature will be the highest, however, radiation strength will be the same throughout the day. If either a block or an entity is exposed to the sun their temperature state will increase (quantity of temperature states can be varied to lower the performance required from slower computers). Their temperature points can be transferred to blocks not exposed to the sun as well, including air blocks which do not absorb heat by sun exposure. Temperature points will decrease if they are not exposed to the sun.

Wind/Thermals –Wind Generation

Wind is a beautiful, peaceful, destructive, and dangerous thing and would be very immersive and interesting in game. Wind is generated when their is a difference in pressure and volume. I encourage the developers to get advice from meteorologists as I am not an expert as to how wind is generated or how much, however, I will give places that I think wind would be found. 

Mountaintops have 4-7 force winds on the Beaufort Scale while the most common is 4.

Beaches: 0-6,  MoCo: 4.

Prairie/Savanna/Tundra: 0-5, MoCo: 2

Nether: 0-4, MoCo: 2

Wind –Diversion

When wind meets a block, the stream terminates there, and the game analyses the environment surrounding the block as well as the velocity of the previous stream. If there is an open space that the wind can flow over to the wind direction is changed to that place. Depending on how far off course this new path is from the original stream, wind strength points are taken away.

This would be so so so awesome!! I've always loved the idea of seasons in Minecraft. I love this game, but the world can sometimes feel stale, like I'm truly the only one progressing in the game. It would be nice to see the world change around me with seasons.

It would also be awesome for winter time to make the rivers and lakes turn into ice, and for the skies to have northern lights, and have high spawn rates of Endermen (since I've always envisioned Endermen and The End to be cold and icy, since there is no Sun or fire in The End), lower spawn rates of spiders (since IRL spiders typically die in the winter), and even rare chances of polar bears spawning in the Winter time for plains biomes and such. This seasons update could also give an excuse to add the Iceologer (or better named the Chillager) and have them spawn during the winter time. It would be awesome for spring and summer to have higher bee and dolphin spawns. The autumn season could have effects where the leaves fall off trees and also turn red, orange, yellow, and so on.

There's so many possibilities with a Seasons Update in Minecraft. I really do hope Mojang considers this update.

I would also love to see seasons in the savanna biome. There is the dry season, which is basically the same as the current savannas, except for the shattered version in Bedrock, which is in the wet season, with vibrant green grass and trees. Thunderstorms during this season will occur almost every afternoon, and ends at early evening, when mob spawning usually starts in clear weather. In some places, the dry season coincides with winter anywhere else, but in other places, there is a very long dry season, with only occasional thunderstorms, but a short wet season, with cloudy skies all day and persistent rainfall.

hmm, the current plants are: Beet, Wheat, Pumpkin, Melon, Mushroom (red and brown) Cocoa beans (excluded) Apple, Potato, Carrot, Glow Berries and Sweet Berries

 

Some of these should receive difficulties during specific seasons

 

Spring: Most crops have boosted or regular growth rates while most of the time leaves turn into sticks or apples

 

Summer: Some crops have difficulty due to some crops only needing so much sunlight, Watermelons are a casualty and grow a little faster, Sweet berries are a little more productive too

 

Fall: Mushrooms need less bone meal to grow and appear on logs sometimes, Potato, Carrot and Wheat crops are slightly slower to grow but give more crops, apples would come out of downed trees more often than empty leaves, Pumpkins are sometimes attacked by Hostile Mobs and turned into cut pumpkins or Jack o' Lanterns, depending on what the real season is (note that this is supposed to make it so it's harder to have your pumpkins near enemies)

 

Winter: Crops that do grow underground (Beet, Potato, Carrot) grow a little faster, potatoes are less likely to be poisonous, while most other Crops have alot more difficulty growing

Maybe in winter, some methods of getting food would be worse or even not possible. Crops would grow slower, oak trees wouldn't have leaves so no apples, and animals might die if not fed properly with wheat. So the game would be much harder on the food front in winter. To conpensate this, there would be less hostile mobs spawning in winter, and more hostile mobs would spawn in summer. The super cold biomes (literal ice and snow) are always like in winter, the super hot biomes (deserts) would always be like in summer. For other biomes, the changes would be more or less intense, depending on the biome. Spring and autumn would have the mob spawning normal and food is also normal. Leaves would fall in autumn, and they would grow back in spring, and more flowers would grow in spring. Also bees would produce more honey in spring.

I think I ultimately have to reiterate that this would be a very fundamental change to the game- and not just the sort of client-side thing you could toggle on or off at whim. While it would certainly offer a lot of new opportunities and game mechanics, it would also be a major undertaking, and clash with existing game mechanics. I think one ultimately has to ask whether such a major change is worth the controversy, as well as the difficulty of implementation and reconciling with existing parts of the game.

For the concerns of having certain features of builds or important parts of the overworld being frozen over or affected in a negative way. How about we have this seasonal update be a part of a new difficulty, called “realism mode”. We already have the easy, medium, hard, hardcore, and adventure modes. Why not add one more name to the roster, to have the features of seasons and survival like gameplay with more realistic features like larger biomes, as well as adding certain passive animals like cows become neutral like wolves so they may attack if provoked. This way it adds new variety to the game and gives a new and fresh experience to players looking for a new challenge with changes to scenery and a harsher survival experience with the cold and affected crop growth. While not harming other players who want the game to stay as it is. The “seasonal update” can also be really beneficial to builders looking to spruce up their custom builds with a few new seasonal blocks, these blocks would obviously be available in the creative menu but also be only obtainable in the “realism difficulty” thus giving an incentive to try out the new feature. I think this way everyone can get the things they look for in Minecraft, and not have this change infringe on the enjoyment of other players who don’t want it. This way both parties benefit and Minecraft gains a brand new brilliant feature to go along with the “beautiful nature” changes Agnes mentioned, in Mojang’s plans for the Wild Update.

I foresee an emphasis on resource strategy with seasons in Minecraft more so than block updates and/or block texture changes. The focus being that some resources may appear more frequently during a specific season for example, would add a 'Minecraft appropriate' level of strategy to resource collection. Also a factor of adding a seasonal efficiency aspect to farming could excite some of the redstone community without freezing all of their item collection systems or snowing all over their observers lol

Also, Copper introduced the passage of time as a building aspect, and I believe seasons can do that too. Just to mention that as a side note.

However, I would rather see changes too resources strategy like plant growth time, animal breeding cooldowns, weather pattern frequency per biome (for snow cauldrons and tridents for example), and mob spawning rules. These three examples could easily express the passage of time in Minecraft without resorting to block state changes like the popular leaf color change suggestion or the freezing water suggestions I have seen in the past. 

Lots more comes to mind, but wanted to share my thoughts on how seasons could impact strategy similarly to how changing ore distribution impacted the strategy of mining. Food for thought, ty mojang <3

I am not sure what would be a good time range, but I think it should take several real life days. Changing seasons so rapidly in the span of a few hours is way too fast.

Some feedback regarding this suggestion, based on my personal experiences with a modded form of seasons:

- Make the seasons toggleable, as well as the crop growth. The look of a biome post-building can detract some players from certain locations in a later season like autumn.
- If toggleable, it should be possible to configure season duration, and make it function for multiple players who use Multisleep.
- If crop growth will be affected by seasons, there has to be a workaround (such as building a greenhouse)
- Tropical biomes can have a 'wet/dry' cycle rather than summer/winter cycle.
- If seasons affect biome temperature and weather, that should also be toggleable. A border between cold/moderate biomes can appear really harsh with snow and rain as you jump borders (worse if you actually built there before knowing any of this..)
- If a biome's temperature drops for winter, snow should form in the biome and water should freeze.
- If weather becomes dependent on season, it should rain more in the spring/autumn, and thunderstorms should be more common in the spring/summer.

Because seasons would affect more than looks in a world, I feel it should be tied to an update to both weather, and potentially crops and farming as a whole. An outlier to this outfit would be the coloration of trees dependent on biomes (I was pretty awed by Terralith and wish elements of it were vanilla)

This would be incredible and make Minecraft Survival especially more realistic and enjoyable. And if players wanted to lock seasons like a day/night cycle they could opt-out. Weather has been something lacking in Minecraft for a long time.

Baby mobs would spawn in spring, less frequently at other times of year. Lambs and calves in spring.

Flowers in spring and summer. Crop growth halting in winter. Pumpkins popping up in autumn. Sweet berries more abundant in autumn. Apples more frequently drop in autumn.

Bees would stay inside their hives during winter.

Perhaps water would freeze but at a slow pace and only when next to a solid block and only at the top layer. That way, coastlines and small ponds would freeze first, ice could be harvested in winter and stored, and water could still be used for irrigation when found beneath ice.

Frogs could become trapped in ice (as they do in real life).
One day is 20 minutes, one month is 10 hours, and one year is 5 days in Minecraft. So every day and 6 hours in starting a world, a new season happens. and maybe have a season-telling item.
One day is 20 minutes, one month is 10 hours, and one year is 5 days in Minecraft. So every day and 6 hours in starting a world, a new season happens. and maybe have a season-telling item.

This addition would be amazing for immersion, particularly if it comes with the option to change how seasons cycle for different worlds and what seasons we can start in. I'd love to see a seasons overhaul also include new tools, building blocks and structure styles to help weather the elements.

We already have copper rods to help redirect lightning, just as one example currently in the live version. Different seasons produce different types of new foliage, block varieties, change up the type of mobs we can see, gives reason to add new mobs (like bears), add additional food and overhaul the current food system to add new cottage/survival themed functional blocks. 

Other survival tools and functions could be tents, rainwater tanks that collect water on a larger scale compared to the cauldron, sleds to transverse across snow and villagers celebrating different festivals depending on the season and being able to collect seasonal trades from them for housing decoration or vanity armors. 

For immersion, we could even collect bugs in jars throughout our travels, like fireflies and butterflies, to decorate our bases.
Making it a setting would also make it that less experienced players could easilier get a hang of the game.

I keep trying to post this as an idea but the website won't let me due to it being too similar so here it is:

Minecraft doesn't need physical weather-changing seasons, it needs seasons of difficulty. Allow me to explain. This would largely center around farming, as a large portion of the game is dependent upon food, yet there are always ways to automate it (something I'm not against, but it removes the survival aspect to me). Have there be a planting/light growth season (to plant crops), a growing season (for the crops to grow), and then a harvest season (to harvest the crops). Perhaps if you didn't harvest them in time, you would get items such as poisonous potatoes much more frequently. And these seasons can last a very large amount of time too while providing the players with something new to do. You could also farm animals as an alternate to crops during food shortages, but remember, you still need crops to breed them, so choose wisely. Villagers may also trade crops, but in seasons of planting, at a higher price.

I also believe that there should be some structure/tool/device that is a physical representation of what farming season the game is in at any given time.

I can envision the timing being that you start in the middle of the first month of Spring (in Java since it starts under a Full Moon night. Bedrock would place you at the end of Late Winter due to it starting under New Moon night). At the end of the third lunar month, it officially transitions into the first month of Summer going into the next month, and after three lunar months of Summer then Autumn starts, and so on. Each season is structured into Early (first month), Mid (middle month), and Late (last month), with it retaining lingering characteristics of the previous season in Early, and early characteristics of the next season in Late, while the Mid month is the present season in full effect.

The new update should add seasons to all biomes to add a nice long term rhythm to the game that players need to factor in when planning exploration or big projects. Winters should be colder, wetter, and darker with shorter days, summers should be hotter, drier, brighter with longer days. Obviously this would be relative to the base biome temperature, so ice spikes would vary between normal cold and dangerously cold, deserts between normal hot and dangerously hot. More temperate biomes could vary from hot summers to cold snowy winters, with tropical biomes having wet and dry seasons.

Individual seasons could last anywhere between 30 and 90 days. Initial spawn should occur in spring to allow players plenty of time to explore, collect resources and build a base ahead of winter. In future updates, season specific items, mobs and challenges could be introduced.

To complement this, a temperature management bar should be added to survival mode. If players are too cold or too hot for an extended period, they receive health damage. Being outside in cold biomes, and particularly getting wet, causes cold exposure which can be relieved with proximity to heat sauces or new fur insulated armour; exertion and being in the direct sun in hot biomes causes heat exposure, which must be relieved through resting in the shade, drinking or eating watery foods, or immersion in water.

In combination, these would really add to the unique and fun challenges of different biomes

Seasons would be a default option in Survival mode, but with a command or option setting to disable or fix for those that don't want them. They would add to the realism and challenge of the game for players who enjoy the constraints of survival mode.

Seasons would cycle every 3 months/90 days in Minecraft time (totally unrelated to the real-world calendar). Every biome would experience seasonal changes, but in different ways that are appropriate to the biome. Every biome would experience longer days in the summer, providing more of an opportunity for exploration, and longer nights in the winter, providing more of a survival challenge. This would set a long-term rhythm to the game that players would enjoy the challenge of adapting to (or if not they could just turn it off!). 

Other than day length, the main changes would be visual (colouration of leaves, grass, etc); weather, crop growing time, mob spawning probabilities; and temperature effects, that could be simultaneously introduced.

Hot arid biomes (desert, badlands etc) would cycle between warm winters and very hot summers

Other tropical biomes (savanna, jungle etc) would cycle between warm, dry winters, and hot, wet summers

Temperature biomes (plains, forests, etc) would have a full 4 season cycle, with some snow in winter

Cold biomes (taiga, meadow, grove) would have a full 4 season cycle, but with snow remaining into the spring

Frozen biomes (plains, peaks, slopes) would have a wet snowy summer and a freezing cold winter

So... I think it's safe to say Proximity chat mods for Minecraft Java and Among Us over the past 12-24 months has been a rip-roaring success to say the least. The Hermitcraft server has just gotten so much livelier with people able to just start chatting whenever they encounter each other. Used to be they'd go, "oh hey that's so and so over there I wonder what they're doing" and just keep going. Now they'll actually wonder over and go, hey what are you doing, or in some cases sneak up on them and creepily look over their shoulder before speaking... hehehehe.

Now the counter, like it or not, bedrock edition is very clearly targeted at the under 18 demographic, especially realms. Thus voice chat is going to need to be an opt in feature, both for the servers and the users, and it will have to run through Xbox services in order for control to be maintained, especially if you want to see this available on private servers (I sure as heck do). That means, lots of dev work for the Xbox services team as well as Mojang. But... with 700+ votes at time of writing... my bet is, someone, somewhere is working on this, but it's going to take at least 6 months before it's ready for testing let alone ready to roll out to the public.

That being said, Minecraft isn't the only game in the "Xbox" ecosystem that would benefit from proximity chat so maybe that side of things has been in progress for awhile and they're just waiting for game devs to implement it.

Makes a lot of sense for Bedrock I think. Legacy Edition had something similar where you could talk to people in your world through voice chat, except it wasn't proximity. There's a big opportunity here for a great (re)addition to the game. Especially for Realms.

I like where you're going with this idea. I absolutely love events in any game I play. Events shake things up and break up the monotony of the game. They are also really fun. Maybe even a wave system, similar to the raid system. I feel that once I get good armor and weapons the combat becomes trivial and stale, even.

However, I do agree with the others who are suggesting a random event instead of an event every single new moon. Also, I think one of 2 things should happen when you try to sleep: You either get a message saying you can't sleep now or you get a warning message informing you that, if you go to sleep, you will be skipping the event. The phase of the moon has two subtle effects on mob spawning:

  • The number of slimes that spawn in swamps is proportional to the moon's fullness: They are most numerous during the full moon, and none spawn during the new moon. (The moon's phase does not influence the normal spawning of slimes in designated chunks at altitudes below y=40.)
  • The fuller the moon, the higher the chance skeletons and zombies have the ability to pick up items and spawn with weapons and armor. Furthermore, there is a higher chance for their equipment to be enchanted, and if it is, the enchantment levels are higher. A fuller moon also gives spiders a greater chance to spawn with random beneficial status effects, including invisibility. All of these effects combine with the world's difficulty; with higher difficulty levels increasing the chance of mob buffs.

Waves would add some lively appearance! I agree with another person's response that the waves should break near the shores, not in the deep.

If anything was going to happen in the deep, it would be swells, which I think could look cool, but I really question if it would be worth the potential trouble (like driving boats through a bunch of fluctuating water blocks...).

Curling waves would be cool for sure, but I would even just be okay with a whitewash effect that pushes you around some like flowing water already does (or like how dolphins do). Something simple, visually peaceful and lively with a slighty fun motion mechanic.

Cherry on top:
In locations where a wave (whitewash) meets a block that is greater than level with the water (Z+1), it would be cool for a small splash against the side of the Z+1 block... like waves hitting a coastal rock wall.

I don't think this could work realistically or at least wouldn't ever be worth the effort for a region stuffed of unique features already.

The reason why is that deep ocean biomes can be hundreds of blocks wide and across so if you were to add moving wave blocks, the number of block updates could be in the 1000s; way too much for Minecraft to realistically run at a decent fps, this works in mods before 1.13 since it only occurs sometimes along the coast and can still be wayyyy too much for some computers.

If however if it were an entity it would have the potential to look better but again, it being essentially a mob but again, entities are even more processing power intensive and would cause problems with the mob cap too.

This leads to the only feasible solution: particle effects. The only thing that would be remotely possible to run would be 10 or so wave particle effects per chunk. This couldn't actually interact with the player but would simulate a current that changed through out the day in deep water biomes. This is already kinda bad and probably couldn't look particularly good.

That being said, why tho? It's not very necessary and I don't think that it would add to the game, even then you would have to argue the hundreds of hours spent on a feature in a place that got one of the biggest updates yet very recently was the best choice in place of a Cave or an End update.

This is something I've been thinking about as well. In my mind, they be able to use water blocks that are able to flow ONTOP of regular water. The waves would be tied to a line of these special water blocks that are teleporting in a specific direction/angle over the water. To keep the waves moving, the water has to flow away from the source blocks fast enough to extend to the furthest block it can before the source block line teleports again. This would be easy to impliment for one-block high waves (would mainly just be tweaking values in a water source copy), but I'm not sure how they would accomplish going any higher than that. They could possibly utilize the new feature of local water levels in caves and impliment it for waves? If they make boats able to float/row up flowing water, then it would be great. I would like to request the addition of split-screen support in Minecraft: Bedrock Edition for Windows 11. This is a feature that clearly exists in the Bedrock version for consoles but has, for some reason, been intentionally removed from the Windows edition.

On consoles, including those of competitors, it is possible to play in split-screen without any issues, while on Microsoft’s own operating system, this functionality is simply unavailable. This does not seem to be a technical limitation but rather an artificial decision that negatively impacts PC players.

Additionally, many people who do not own consoles would like to play Minecraft with friends and family on their TVs using controllers. However, the lack of split-screen support prevents this possibility, making the Windows 11 experience inferior without any clear justification.

Adding split-screen support would make the Windows 11 experience more complete and accessible, allowing more players to enjoy the game in the same way it is already available on consoles. I hope you reconsider this decision and bring the feature to the PC version.

Do you have any information on a potential timeline for Bedrock Edition’s availability on macOS? This would complete the universality of Bedrock Edition and would finally allow for the depreciation and phasing out of the Java Edition. That has to be the eventual goal from a business perspective.

Recently Mojang has been pushing both Bedrock and Java as a combined package deal to sell the game. However, for MacOS users they may buy the same package and yet are only capable of using Minecraft Java Edition. Seeing as how both games are being pushed as a package deal, Minecraft would likely sell more if both games were actually offered to MacOS users. I would also like to make it apparent that Minecraft Bedrock Edition is available on IOS rather than Java (due to system compatibility issues), making Bedrock popular. In the past this might have been incentivized by users buying both versions, but seeing as how now both editions are being sold together this no longer holds any incentive. Rather, there are many disincentives that come along with Bedrock Edition not being available. Bedrock players would like to play MC on their Macs and will pay for it. These audiences are likely to buy the packaged deal if Minecraft Bedrock Edition is made available on MacOS. This is true because they’re able to maintain their communities and groups they play with on Bedrock Edition, while also exploring Minecraft Java Edition. Moving forward I see MC Bedrock Edition being made available to MacOS users as both a legitimate way to make money for Mojang, along with a way for longtime Bedrock players to enjoy the version they are used to. Both interests align and therefore pursuing the release of MC Bedrock Edition on MacOS will be in the best interest of players and developers alike.

We all love new content—new biomes to explore, new structures to loot, and new mobs to tame or fight. But right now, the most critical upgrade MCPE needs isn't a new block; it's basic, functional communication.
We need built-in, cross-platform voice chat more than any other feature.
While a new structure is a temporary novelty, voice chat is the foundation of modern, collaborative multiplayer.
Why VC is a Higher Priority:
* True Cross-Play: We play on Bedrock so we can connect with friends on PC, console, and mobile. But connecting isn't enough; we need to communicate efficiently. Typing on a small screen or pausing the game to type a complex message breaks the flow and puts us at a huge disadvantage against PC players who can type almost instantly. VC levels the playing field.
* Seamless Collaboration: Imagine building a massive project, fighting the Warden, or setting up a complex Redstone circuit. Trying to coordinate this with text chat is slow, clunky, and often leads to mistakes. Voice chat enables real-time strategy, quick directions, and instant teamwork.
* Community and Connection: Minecraft is a social game. VC makes the multiplayer experience more engaging, fun, and personal. It fosters genuine community on servers and lets us feel closer to our friends, no matter what device they're using.
A new mob is cool, but voice chat is what truly modernizes the Bedrock experience and unlocks the full potential of cross-play. Let's prioritize the feature that enables

Built-In Voice Chat for Minecraft Bedrock / Pocket Edition

Category: Features & Gameplay

Description:

I think Minecraft Bedrock / Pocket Edition should have a built-in voice chat feature in the game itself. It should be added as an official feature in a future minor update, so players can talk to each other directly without needing any external apps or mods.

The voice chat option could appear in the Settings menu, just like other accessibility or audio settings. There could also be a push-to-talk button or an automatic voice detection option for easier communication on mobile, console, and Windows.

Many multiplayer games already include built-in voice chat, and it makes the overall gaming experience much more social and enjoyable. Being able to talk while building, exploring, or surviving together would make Minecraft even better for friends and community players.

Currently, Minecraft Bedrock players have no safe or official way to use voice chat, unlike Java players who have mods for it. That’s why it would be amazing if Mojang officially adds built-in voice chat to Bedrock Edition in an upcoming minor update.

This would greatly improve teamwork, communication, and fun for millions of players worldwide!

This is the way I imagine the mechanic would work:

You can right-click to lie down in a bed any time, and just like on multi-player servers, if it is daytime and not thundering, or there are other players not sleeping, you will just lie there.

When night or a thunderstorm arrives, if all players logged in are also in bed, the normal amount of time will be skipped as usual except you are not kicked out of bed when the day comes. You still lie in the bed (like you're sleeping in), until you click "Leave Bed". I think this adds the nice touch that getting out of bed is an active choice you must make, rather than something that just happens to you.

This would also make AFK-ing in the overworld less annoying to other players on small servers, since you could lie in bed constantly, and keep skipping the night whenever all the other players go to bed.

Additionally, for people who like to role play their Minecraft adventures, it gives a player the opportunity to yawn, rub their eyes, and say "A big day today, need to get an early start!", click "Leave Bed", and then do a few stretches.

Feels more natural than the current "ok, time to sleep"... "eyes closing"..."GAH! It's daytime!". It makes Steve seem like he's always waking up from nightmares.

To make either more useful and effective, rather than "skipping the night" this alternate use can simply make it so mobs do not spawn in X radios around you. Both are simple, and they give the bed a dynamic use outside of just "skip the night".

Lighting doesn't hit more conductive things more frequently though... the reason lightning rods are made of metal is so they can transfer the energy into the ground to not cause any damage. If they were made of wood, for example, it would explode upon it being hit by lighting because the energy would have trouble transferring through the wood. Lighting does, however, hit the highest object because energy tries to take the path of least resistance, which usually means traveling the shortest distance.

I personally love this idea, but I think the drawbacks are on the technological side of the game. Ever since Microsoft has taken control of Mojang, their focus has been to make the game as accessible and connected as possible as seen with both the heavy optimizations and the cross-platform capabilities of Minecraft: Bedrock Edition. Doubling the height limit would increase world sizes by orders of magnitude, changing a 65536 block chunk to a 131072 block chunk, every chunk, for the entire world. This would probably take a lot of changes to fix how the world generate, save, and may not be viable for weaker systems like phones. I really really love this idea but I think that it's going to take a lot of convincing, and a lot of pros, to get the devs on it.

A problem which appears when using the "cubic chunks" approach is lighting and crop growth issues:

There is no easy to compute way of checking for sky light – the solution open cubic chunks provides is pretty memory intensive. (more info on that)

At some level it bothers me that the lighting issue seems to be such a problem for this idea. It is certainly not an unsolvable problem, reducing memory consumption for lighting data is a matter of compressing opacity data, essentially because all you are doing is searching for the next opaque block, smart data structures can compress 1000's of chunks worth of opacity into a few bits of data simply by adding a little meta data to the lighting info and creating clusters of chunks.

Using a single byte of meta data, you could determine whether either the entire chunk, 4 chunks, 16, and so on to 16,384 chunks of data are transparent. Quickly identifying the next opaque block millions of blocks away really doesn't require the engine to search every block.

Honestly the world doesn't need to be millions of blocks tall, but within this methodology alone, you would be able to find the next opaque block to any location in 8 lookups to a world 262,144 blocks tall. And arguably the way the world loads chunks 256 blocks tall at the moment, the memory required for solving light would be reduced.

The Short answer to your question is that if the solution reworks how the world loads chunks, possibly to something like cubic chunks, it shouldn't affect performance - if they just double the world height and don't look to how the system works it will make everything slower.

My idea is that the infinity portal would be an ultra endgame feature:

There would be the ultimate structure: The infinity tower(Or any better name, I’m pretty bad at choosing names)

Only one infinity tower would generate per world. It can be in almost all biomes and profundities. It would be very big (100 x 30 x 100 blocks), made of stone bricks and its variants. Its shape is like a dome, and in ruins. The inside resembles a castle and it is full of hostile mobs (except illagers) and complex redstone traps. There is a good loot in chests, but the most valuable thing there is the portal, in the center of the building.

The portal room has walls and ceiling of obsidian, and the portal isn’t lit. To charge it, players have to craft the power sphere(I already said I’m bad with names?) with a dragon egg in the center, four nether stars in the corners, one block of netherite in the top, one block of diamond in the bottom, and two eternity totems in the sides. The only use of the power sphere is to light the portal (sorry for everyone who thought in making a sword with it). And after you light the portal, something goes out of it...

The final boss, Superior Level. And this time, you won’t win easily, because your opponent... is YOU!

Superior level has Steve’s or Alex’s skin, if the player uses one of those. Otherwise it is randomly decided. (And can it have white glowing eyes too?)

It uses a obsidian armor (enchanted) and can teleport, mine blocks very quickly with obsidian tools (also enchanted) and give 10 hearts of damage with the obsidian sword (enchanted too). It also has a bow(enchanted), powerful effects(regeneration, resistance, strength and others, depending on the difficulty) and can place blocks. He has 20 hearts of health and attack everything (but will prioritize the player and won’t attack anything until the player is dead or something is attacking it.

If killed, the portal’s color will change to white (or another color that fits better) and won’t change, no matter what. When the player enters it, they will be in a castle or mansion (Superior Level’s lair). This dimension is similar to the overworld, but is always night and thunderstorm, and no mobs will spawn there. Then, a piston door will open and Superior Level will be at the other side, and destroy the return portal when see the player (it respawned), but with netherite armor, weapons and tools, and potions instead of effects. It will try to protect a blue block, called respawning block, which makes it respawn when killed, but with worse equipment. If the block is destroyed, Superior Level can be killed for good. When it is finally killed, the return portal will reappear and the player will have the infinity portal.

Oh, and instead of using normal books, the portal is changed with special books that need to be signed with a kind of enchanted table for books, that costs some levels of Xp.

I think this will be a great challenge.

These are my ideas, hope you liked!

Instead of using a basic nether portal, perhaps it must be a *special* portal whose frame is constructed from a composite of the new rarer materials.

A frame of Crying Obsidian connected to a Lodestone and a Respawn Anchor, then powered with the sacrifice of a Nether Star.

Lore-compliant and mechanically consistent:
 - Crying Obsidian is obsidian that has been saturated with overloaded portal energy.
 - The Lodestone focuses and refines the portal energy seeping from the crying obsidian enough to resolve it into a coherent field.
 - The Respawn Anchor facilitates the connection to the other universe, ensuring that transit back and forth between realms is secure.
 - The Nether Star supercharges the Crying Obsidian, replenishing its portal energy saturation indefinitely as it pours that energy into the field.

The "Infinity" snapshot features were just too great an idea to be limited to a single April fool's snapshot on Java. Mojang would be fools indeed to let this one fall by the wayside.

That said, there should be the possibility of programming a custom dimension's generation, both in-game and by modding.

Instead of all the biomes in the April fool's, they could just make it generate single biome world's (and things like flat world's) with varied points of interest density, mob spawning rates and resource generation.

To balance it, use expensive material to both inscribe the books and have the table be made of rare materials. You can also use the same menu for the enchanting table, where books are level tied, cost levels and possibly something like netherite scrap to inscribe. Beds still explode, different sky's and portal colors to give an obvious your not in the overworld. Can also have things like an always night and always rainy/thunderstorm planes. Planes like flat world being cheep, and storm world costing more level & required levels. The enchanting table style would make it easy to the player to pick a book from a list and easier on the programmer to curate books. It'll also make it where the player can try out different worlds well not having to start from scratch, adding to a world's replayability.

Creators/modders could make resource packs that add books [name, color (portal/sky), biome, weather, spawnrate, POI density] and just use the last 3 to level the book that way it can't break the game.

The 20w14infinite snapshot is, by far, my favorite Minecraft thing to be released in a long time. As new blocks are implemented, it would be great to have them be able to spawn in “infinity dimensions” in newer versions, instead of having to stay with only Nether Update features and below when playing with these dimensions in the original snapshot. Bringing it to Bedrock Edition would also be important for parity. 

However, I don’t think it should be added to worlds without it enabled as an option, because of balance issues for Survival players, and I think the “joke” dimensions should stay. At least keep “Skygrid” and “Bridges”, please.

Adding this feature will be about as OP as creative mode is OP. I watch my young kids play all day in creative mode and infinite access to stuff doesn’t ruin the game for them, instead it actually makes the game accessible to them. So based on that, I counter the argument that it would destroy the nature of Minecraft.

Let Minecraft survival endgame stay sane, but add this feature for fun, via cheats.

As for the bloat it would cause for mobile users... well yes and no. An infinite overworld has the same potential to bloat, albeit quite a bit slower. But I know that I could create 100 new worlds on my device for the thrill of adventuring and discovery and I would end up running out of space. There would need to be a cloud offloading management feature added perhaps.

Bloat could also be mitigated by making dimension worlds limited to a certain number of chunks if they are to be persistent rather than transient dimensions. This could be determined by the user (as it currently is, with the create world type selector [flat/infinite/old]) or by device resource limitations.

I also like the “dual seed” idea. Instead of just having the text directly seed the dimension, have the book text hash with the world seed (or perhaps the portal coordinates/geometry/any combination of variables to salt the hash)

Doing so would add an astonishing intrigue that would make for countless experiences.

Likewise, from a normal world, being able to build a portal to get *to* various different buffet worlds could also be neat.

Refining the idea, it would be interesting if the game rule had options:

  • Full chaos as implemented in the joke snapshot.
  • Sanitized chaos as has been suggested by others (removing the worst options but leave most)
  • Buffet worlds, where the alternate dimensions are limited to a single buffet world for each biome.

This solves the balance issues, and makes it more useful. I don't think end-game access to a buffet world of each biome type is going to unbalance anything.

I don't understand the hesitation when it comes to spawners. The only things they would be decent for would be larger scale blaze, drowned and skeleton farms. Skeleton farms are practically useless because crimson nylium flower farms give stupidly high amounts of bone meal, and bows and low tier armour aren't really worth farming. Drowned farms are useful for copper but to make a semi efficient farm with spawners would make the structure huge, not really worth it for anything else. Larger blaze farms would be pretty useful though, but not overpowered. There are much more efficient ways of gaining XP without the use of spawners (guardian farms, gold farms, even furnaces), and fuel is extremely easy to farm in multiple different ways (wither skeletons, kelp, bamboo, trees). My point being, the idea is good and silk touch II doesn't need to be insanely rare for it to be balanced, at least in the way OP has set it up. Having an enchantment that allows players to obtain breakable unobtainable items is just a cool thing to have imo. Not gamebreaking but not entirely useless either

Adding Offhand Feature and New Buttons

Hello Mojang Team,

I would like to request a new feature for Minecraft Bedrock Edition — full offhand support just like in the Java Edition. Right now, the offhand slot in Bedrock is very limited and can only hold a few specific items like shields or totems.

It would be great if Bedrock players could use the offhand for more items, such as torches, food, maps, and arrows. This would make survival and exploration much easier and more balanced between Java and Bedrock editions.

Also, please consider adding new customizable button options, especially for mobile and console players. For example, a separate button to use or switch offhand items, and the ability to rearrange or resize buttons freely on the screen.

These changes would make gameplay more flexible, comfortable, and fair for all Bedrock players.
Thank you for reading and for continuing to make Minecraft better! 💚

This change is very essential for a good Cave Update. Currently we mostly have about 60-70 blocks to dig until we reach the bedrock, which makes mining very easy and boring. For a good Cave Update, underground should be layered and the depth of it should at least be quadrupled. What I mean by layered is that blocks should be harder to break and the difficulty level of caves should also increase (with traps, with environmental hazards such as lava, poisonous plants, blocks that slow you down etc. and most importantly with new and strong hostile mobs!) as the player digs down. If this is not done correctly, the update will be very disappointing. P.S if someone from Mojang is reading this, Terraria's underground is a perfect example for you to be inspired by.

Antvenom of all people came up with a clever solution to this problem for raising the Nether roof. Same problem, essentially.

The best way not to have old worlds affected by the update is to simply... raise them. If the new sea level is at 128, modify all of the old world's entity and block data to be 64 blocks above what it currently is. That might take awhile, but the load time only happens once.

When bordering new cave update chunks, simply create a vertical bedrock wall from y = 0 to y = 64. And then, that's it! Old world converted. What's essentially left is for the devs to decide on if they want to do this or not.

Hell yeah!! It only makes sense, since we have giant mountains, room for mining, followed by giant caverns, more room for mining for diamond and iron, deeper still caves, and the deep dark biome! Minecraft has amazing potential for world generation, but the minimal world height makes the underground disappointing, so a severe increase in chunk height alongside the cave update would bring an incredible level of exploration potential to the worlds.
The best way to implement this without making the game perform far worse is by having the game use Cubic chunk generation (16x16x16) so the entire underground below you isn't fully loaded.

I hate to burst players bubbles but the Mojang devs have already confirmed they're not increasing the build limits or adding cubic chunks in 1.17...

I DO however think that there is a good solution here that could still satisfy players and give larger caves though.  Currently, the highest mountains typically only generate up to Y 150~.  If Mojang raises the ground level, water level, etc. by another 50~ blocks that still gives another 50~ blocks for the new mountains as well before hitting the 256 block height limit.

While I don't think this would necessarily be as good as increasing build heights or cubic chunks, it does seem like the easiest and most practical solution to the issue.  Even adding an extra 20-30 blocks to the underground could make a world of difference!
